occurrences.line_text: Him to aggrate, and greatest pleasures shew;
Does shew to him, that walkes in feare and sad affright.
But wrought by art and counterfetted shew,
Such life ye read, and vertue in vaine shew,
Then gan Sir Guyon all the story shew
She graunted, & them leading forth, the same did shew.
That him full of melancholy did shew;
For some like Snailes, some did like spyders shew,
The horrible Sea-satyre, that doth shew
First did it shew the bitter balefull stowre,
That glistred all with gold and glorious shew,
Basciante did him selfe most curteous shew;
It vertue had, to shew in perfect sight,
Shall of him selfe a braue ensample shew,
Hee turnd againe, and chearefull looks as earst did shew.
And all her whole creation did her shew
Both shew their auncestrie.
Their vapour vaded, shew their golden gleames,
Was neuer better time to shew thy smart,
For shew of perill, without venturing:
To shew Dan Cupids powre and great effort:
To shew the victors might and mercilesse intent.
And outward shew faire semblance they did beare;
But that such as she was, she plaine did shew;
Assembled were their deedes of armes to shew.
Then did Sir Ferramont vnto them shew
Her louely Amoret did open shew;
She seem'd to passe: so forged things do fairest shew.
To come and shew themselues before the light,
Ne signe of sence did shew, ne common wit,
On him, whilst goodly grace she did him shew:
Shew gladsome countenaunce nor pleasaunt glee:
And faint-heart-fooles, whom shew of perill hard
The which right well her workes diuine did shew:
Whose like none else could shew, the which they Ruffins call.
And for no cause, but as I shall you shew.
In stead of right me seemes great wrong dost shew,
There Marinell great deeds of armes did shew;
Against them durst his head to perill shew.
Came Braggadochio, and did shew his shield,
For proofe shew forth thy sword, and let it tell,
Or shew the wounds, which vnto thee befell;
Or shew the sweat, with which thou diddest sway
They shouted loud, and signes of gladnesse all did shew.
And what a glorious shew he made in all their sights.
With daily shew of courteous kind behauiour,
So daily he faire semblant did her shew,
To shew that Isis doth the Moone portend;
To shew that she had powre in things diuine;
By outward shew her inward sence defining.
To shew that clemence oft in things amis,
That Lion-like shall shew his powre extreame.
As they vpon him prest, it plaine to them did shew.
That vnder shew oftimes of fayned semblance,
To whom he wont shew all the shame he might,
She gan reioyce, and shew triumphant chere,
Who will not mercie vnto others shew,
To shew her thankefull mind and meaning faine,
And vnto him did shew all louely courtesyes.
Doth noble courage shew, with curteous manners met.
Crying aloud to shew her sad misfare
Did shew it selfe in sunny beames bedight,
Yet will it shew some sparkes of gentle mynd,
The couert was so thicke, that did no passage shew.
Those euill tidings to their Lord to shew.
To shew such faintnesse and foule cowardize,
That neuer more they should endure the shew
Like the faire Morning clad in misty fog did shew.
Some shew of fauour, by him gracing small,
Nor better cheare to shew in misery,
To shew the courtesie by him profest,
He shew'd him painted in a table plaine,
In word and deede that shew'd great modestie,
So faire and fresh that Lady shewd her selfe in sight.
He shewd that day, and rare ensample made,
And shewd them naked, deckt with many ornaments.
Whose pleasaunce she him shew'd, and plentifull great store.
That nought but desert wildernesse shew'd all around.
And shewd of richesse such exceeding store,
To weet, whence all the wealth late shewd by mee,
Of so great graces, as ye haue me shewd,
And shewd him many sights, that courage cold could reare.
But rather shewd more white, if more might bee:
But shewd by outward signes, that dread her sence did daze.
And shewd her selfe in all a gentle curteous Dame.
It shewd it selfe, and shone vnwillingly;
Then shewd it, how the Thebane Semelee
Yet in that horror shewd a seemely grace,
And shame, he shewd him selfe to be dismayd,
He open shewd, that all men it mote marke.
Shew'd all his bodie bare vnto the cruell dent.
And shew'd themselues to her, such as indeed they were.
Shew'd change of better cheare: so sore a breach
Ne euer laught, ne once shew'd countenance glad;
Whose bloudie corse they shew'd him there beside,
And shew'd him how through error and mis-thought
And shew'd that she had not that Lady reft,
And shew'd, that with his Lord she would emparlaunce make.
With these his wicked sons, and shewd his cankred hate.
Her selfe most gratefull shew'd, & heaped thanks repayd.
Which being shew'd, he gan him selfe streight way
In which she shew'd, how that discourteous knight
Witnesse thereof he shew'd his head there left,
Yet shewd some token of his gentle blood,
But one still towards shew'd her selfe afore;
So shew'd them her, to proue how pale & weake she was.
Shew'dst thou, then in this royall Maid of yore,
To Satyrane she shewed her intent:
Into this world, and shewed heauens light,
There this old Palmer shewed himselfe that day,
Whom Alma hauing shewed to her guestes,
That thou hast shewed to me sinfull wight,
Which Clotho graunting, shewed her the same:
So soone as heauens window shewed light,
Whereat they shewed curteous countenaunce.
Full many deedes that day were shewed plaine:
And euer in her bow she ready shewed
Yet neither shewed to other their hearts priuity.
And in her semblant shewed great womanhood:
And shewed her to him, then being sore bestad.
Yet chearefull signes he shewed outwardly.
Next Hercules his like ensample shewed,
Like as the sea (which plaine he shewed there)
And vnto all himselfe there open shewed,
And these the signes, (so shewed forth his wounds)
Directed in, and shewed all the sight:
And what she had not seene, within vnto her shewed.
Then in he brought her, and her shewed there
To whom faire semblance, as he could, he shewed
He shewed semblant of exceeding mone,
Ne euer shewed signe of foule disloyalty.
Which Turpine had vnto her shewed late,
Ne euer shewed signe of rancour or of iarre.
To whom they shewed, how those marchants were
And with false shewes abuse his fantasy,
And to my loathed life now shewes some light,
Yet outwardly some little comfort shewes:
And shewes the way, his sinfull soule to saue.
And darksom dens, where Titan his face neuer shewes.
And Guyon in them all shewes goodly maisteries.
With such vaine shewes thy worldlings vile abuse:
Shewes, visions, sooth-sayes, and prophesies;
And shewes the famous Progeny
And shewes his powre in variable kinds:
Neither of idle shewes, nor of false charmes aghast.
And sheweth each thing, as it is indeed:
Which speaking token sheweth at the least
As for this Ladie, which he sheweth here,
Shewing her selfe both wise and liberall:
Shewing desire her inward flame to slake:
Shewing his nature in his countenance;
And shewing her, did Paridell vpbray;
Then shewing forth signes of their fathers blood,
Shewing him selfe all ready for the field.
Saluagesse sans finesse, shewing secret wit.
Midst sorrow shewing ioyous semblance for his sake.
And heauens laugh, & all the world shews ioyous cheare.
And shewst th'ensa[m]ple of thy childish might,
Vpon his shield the like was also scor'd,
Lept fierce vpon his shield, and her huge traine
And siluer shield vpon his coward brest
In whose great shield was writ with letters gay
And glauncing downe his shield, from blame him fairely blest.
The Sarazins shield, signe of the conqueroure.
By his like seeming shield, her knight by name
And on his shield Sans loy in bloudie lines was dyde.
Through vainely crossed shield he quite did pierce,
Through shield and bodie eke he should him beare:
And ramping on his shield, did weene the same
He hath his shield redeem'd, and foorth his sword he drawes.
And heathnish shield, wherein with letters red
Who when the shamed shield of slaine Sans foy
And if that either to that shield had right,
Whose shield he beares renuerst, the more to heape disdayn.
His worthy shield, whom he with guilefull snare
Yea but (quoth she) he beares a charmed shield,
Sans-foy his shield is hangd with bloudy hew:
Vpon his brothers shield, which hong thereby:
Whilest here thy shield is hangd for victors hyre,
That I his shield haue quit from dying foe.
The false Duessa, Thine the shield, and I, and all.
Goe say, his foe thy shield with his doth beare.
The conquest yours, I yours, the shield, and glory yours.
And to him brought the shield, the cause of enmitie.
And catching vp in hast his three square shield,
Or get his shield, his monstrous enimy
His siluer shield, now idle maisterlesse;
His warlike shield all closely couer'd was,
Before that shield did fade, and suddeine fall:
Both shield, and sword, and armour all he wrought
The stroke vpon his shield so heauie lites,
And in his fall his shield, that couered was,
At flashing beames of that sunshiny shield,
In that bright shield, and all their forces spend
And high emongst all knights hast hong thy shield,
Quite through his shield, and in his shoulder seasd,
Vpon his sunne-bright shield, and gript it fast withall.
The other foot, fast fixed on his shield,
But hong still on the shield, as it at first was pight.
Vpright he rode, and in his siluer shield
Which on your shield is set for ornament:
That decks and armes your shield with faire defence:
And that deare Crosse vpon your shield deuizd,
His sunbroad shield about his wrest he bond,
And on his shield like yron sledges bet:
And many-folded shield he bound about his wrest.
Withouten sword or shield, an host to quaile?
Behind his backe he bore a brasen shield,
To be the shield of some redoubted knight;
In the meant marke, aduaunst his shield atweene,
On his broad shield, bit not, but glauncing fell
Of his seuenfolded shield away it tooke,
That on his shield depainted he did see;
Cymochles sword on Guyons shield yglaunst,
Ne all good knights, that shake well speare and shield:
And of that shield, more worthy of good knight;
With that, rude hand vpon his shield he laid,
And couerd shield. Well kend him so farre space
And Guyons shield about his wrest he bond;
That seuen-fold shield, which he from Guyon brought
For in his shield, as thicke as stormie showre,
At proud Cymochles, whiles his shield was wyde,
The one vpon his couered shield did fall,
Ne shield defend the thunder of his throwes:
Who Guyons shield cast euer him before,
And looking vp, when as his shield he lakt,
Of my good sword and shield? The Palmer glad,
And Guyon his lost shield, they both yfere
To weet why on your shield so goodly scord
Whose faire retrait I in my shield do beare;
The greene shield dyde in dolorous vermell?
Vpon his shield their heaped hayle he bore,
Vpon his shield, that it no further went,
And his bright shield, that nought him now auayld,
And his braue shield, full of old moniments,
That seem'd to couch vnder his shield three-square,
And on his arme addresse his goodly shield
That seem'd both shield & plate it would haue riued;
To tossen speare and shield, and to affrap
What shape, what shield, what armes, what steed, what sted,
And on his shield enueloped seuenfold
Auenge his fathers losse, with speare and shield,
The dreadfull speare and shield to exercize:
Both speare she tooke, and shield, which hong by it:
Both speare & shield of great powre, for her purpose fit.
Where be the battels, where the shield and speare,
Eftsoones her goodly shield addressing faire,
But she againe him in the shield did smite,
His vncouth shield and straunge armes her dismayd,
His speare amids her sun-broad shield arriued;
And her Gorgonian shield gins to vntye
Where I expected one with shield and spere,
A little off, his shield was rudely throwne,
Her ample shield she threw before her face,
Gainst whom he alwaies bent a brasen shield,
And with great glorie both the shield of loue,
To them appear'd, with shield and armour fit;
I wote not well, but in his shield he beares
Through shield and mayle, and haberieon did wend,
And Triamond to handle speare and shield,
And throughly skild in vse of shield and speare;
That forced him his shield to disaduaunce:
With doubled force close vnderneath his shield,
Close vnderneath his shield, that scarce did show,
Vpon the brim of his brode plated shield,
Of knights, addrest his maiden-headed shield,
The shield and armes well knowne to be the same,
For to haue rent his shield and armes away,
His word, which on his ragged shield was writ,
And vow'd with speare and shield it to maintaine;
Vnto her sword and shield her soone betooke;
Vpon his shield, which lightly he did throw
The shield it droue, and did the couering reare:
Through which this shield of loue I late haue wonne,
And that both shield and she whom I behold,
On which this shield, of many sought in vaine,
The shield of Loue, whose guerdon me hath graced,
VVhose euer be the shield, faire Amoret be his.
But with my speare vpon the shield did rap,
And taking downe the shield, with me did it retaine.
Bearing the shield which I had conquerd late,
Eftsoones aduauncing that enchaunted shield,
With that my shield I forth to her did show,
But euermore my shield did me defend,
And as I marked, bore vpon his shield,
And by the other markes, which of his shield he tooke.
Then to approue his right with speare and shield.
To change his shield with him, to be better hid.
To Braggadochio did his shield restore:
Came Braggadochio, and did shew his shield,
That shield, which thou doest beare, was it indeed,
And this the arme, the which that shield did beare,
Then from him reft his shield, and it renuerst,
And on her shoulder hung her shield, bedeckt
But with her shield so well her selfe she warded,
Halfe of her shield he shared quite away,
Yet with her shield she warded it againe,
Hauing her thus disarmed of her shield,
And with his single shield, well as he might,
Till he to her deliuered had his shield,
She quickly caught her sword, & shield about her bound.
That she her shield through raging smart of it
At last from his victorious shield he drew
Soone as the infants sunlike shield they saw,
Onely his shield and armour, which there lay,
And purchase it to vs with speare and shield:
Into the Princes shield, where it empight;
Into his shield it readie passage found,
Past through his shield, & pierst through either syde,
That had he chaunced not his shield to reare,
But th'Adamantine shield, which he did beare,
Thereto addresse, and his bright shield display.
The armed Prince, with shield so blazing bright,
And on his shield tooke hold with all her might,
To loose his shield, and long while did contend:
And thrown his shield atween, she had him done to rew.
That they his shield in peeces battred haue,
Your owne good shield in daungerous dismay?
Gaue me a shield, in which he did endosse
But for that many did that shield enuie,
Your honours stile, that is your warlike shield.
My former shield I may resume againe:
And blames for changing shield:
And cast his shield about, to be in readie plight.
And stouped oft his head from shame to shield;
And twixt him and the blow his shield did cast,
His axe he could not from his shield vndoe.
But loosing soone his shield, did it forgoe,
So off he did his shield, and downeward layd
Tho on his shield he griple hold did lay,
So nigh at hand, nor force his shield to straine,
Both speare and shield, as things that needlesse were,
Then taking vp that Recreants shield and speare,
His shield, his helmet, and his curats bare.
That on his shield did rattle like to haile
Full in the shield, with so impetuous powre,
Dismounting light, his shield about him threw,
Did cast his shield atweene, and therewithall
His shield he on him threw, and fast downe held;
Y cladd in mightie armes and siluer shielde,
Which shielded them against the boyling heat,
And in that right should by all knights be shielded:
Their shining shieldes about their wrestes they tye,
As from a forge out of their burning shields,
And clash their shields, and shake their swords on hy,
That from their shields forth flyeth firie light,
Bespotted all with shields of red and blacke,
His blazing eyes, like two bright shining shields,
Gan with new rage their shields to hew and cut;
Faire shields, gay steedes, bright armes be my delight:
Disshiuered speares, and shields ytorne in twaine,
And shields did share, & mailes did rash, and helmes did hew.
And gan their shields addresse them selues afore:
By scattered shields was easie to be showen.
Hewing, and slashing shields, and helmets bright,
Amid their shields, with so huge might and maine,
And then assayle him fresh, ere he could shift for more.
All passengers, that none from it can shift:
Which whenas none she fond, with easie shift,
But he to shift their curious request,
He could his weapon shift from side to syde,
One time, when he his weapon faynd to shift,
To giue him ground, and shift to euery side,
Foure times his place he shifted hath in sight,
But with slie shiftes and wiles did vnderminde
For to maligne, t'enuie, t'vse shifting slight,
That when the knight beheld, his mightie shild
Like Phoebus lampe throughout the world doth shine,
Mine, that did then shine as the Morning starre:
Then gan her beautie shine, as brightest skye,
And all embrewd in bloud, his eyes did shine as glas.
And round about her head did shine like heauens light.
And opened his dull eyes, that light mote in them shine.
In heauenly throne, where thousand Angels shine?
Did shine with siluer, and shoot forth his beame.
Did euer see vpon this world to shine,
These warlike Champions all in armour shine,
Whose beauties beame eftsoones did shine so bright,
Doest fayrest shine, and most adorne thy place,
Then shine in learning, more then euer did
Begins to turne, and sunne to shine more bright,
Whose goodly light then Phebus lampe doth shine more cleare?
His glitterand armour shined farre away,
Vpon the trembling waue, so shined bright,
Thrice shined faire, and thrice seem'd dim and wan,
Did fall in loue: yet this much fairer shined,
Vppon the bosse with stones, that shined wide,
Ne vnder Sunne, that shines so wide and faire,
Proud of his Adamants, with which he shines
Whose glory shineth as the morning starre,
To frame such subtile wire, so shinie cleare.
Vnto the shinie heauen in haste she hide,
But when as daies faire shinie-beame, yclowded
Dimmed her former beauties shining ray,
But welcome now my light, and shining lampe of blis.
Their shining shieldes about their wrestes they tye,
Adornd with gold and iewels shining cleare,
And shining helmet, soone him buckled to the field.
His blazing eyes, like two bright shining shields,
What if within the Moones faire shining spheare?
Most ioyous man, on whom the shining Sunne,
His shining Helmet he gan soone vnlace,
All pau'd beneath with Iaspar shining bright,
Such was the beautie and the shining ray,
Defast the beautie of the shining sky,
Faire ympes of beautie, whose bright shining beames
Like as the shining skie in summers night,
Nor shining gold, nor mouldring clay it was;
With shining gold, and arched ouer hed,
Like the faire yuory shining they did see,
With starrie beames about her shining bright,
So pure and shiny, that the siluer flood
His ship farre come from watrie wildernesse,
As when a ship, that flyes faire vnder saile,
As weather-beaten ship arriu'd on happie shore.
As a tall ship tossed in troublous seas,
Eftsoones her shallow ship away did slide,
The Idle lake, my wandring ship I row,
Learning his ship from those white rocks to saue,
They passing by, a goodly Ship did see,
And brauely furnished, as ship might bee,
Vnder the ship, as thorough them she went,
The which may bring my ship, ere it be rent,
Like as a ship, whose Lodestarre suddenly
Yet without ship or bote her thence to row,
Like as a ship, whom cruell tempest driues
A ship all readie (as good fortune fell)
Like as a ship with dreadfull storme long tost,
Like as a ship, that through the Ocean wyde
Ne made for shipping any certaine port,
To weete if shipping readie he mote there descry.
And twise renforst, backe to their ships to fly,
And shiuered ships, which had bene wrecked late,
The flying ships with swiftnesse to pursew,
Did afterwards make shipwracke violent,
But suffred cruell shipwracke by the way.
And of him selfe doth name the shire thereby;
And shiuered ships, which had bene wrecked late,
Of broken bowes and arrowes shiuered short,
By shiuered speares, and swords all vnder strowen,
But shiuered all about, and scattered in the wynd.
That all his launce in peeces shiuered quite,
And shiuering speare in bloudie field first shooke,
The Parthian strikes a stag with shiuering dart,
With that they gan their shiuering speares to shake,
He all enrag'd, his shiuering speare did shake,
A shiuering dart with so impetuous force,
In thousand shiuers, and so forth beside her past.
Do meete, that with the terrour of the shocke
That with the shocke of their owne heedlesse might,
Shapt like a horses shoe, who list to seeke it there.
And thred-bare cote, and cobled shoes he ware,
That ouer shoes in bloud he waded on the ground.
And shoke his scales to battell readie drest;
By which she thought her wandring knight shold pas,
Where beauties prize shold win that pretious spoyle:
For feare her mistresse shold haue knowledge gayned,
In the next brooke, by who[m] that feend shold be fordonne.
And wondrous sholes, which may of none be red.
Soone as that vncouth light vpon them shone,
But ere my hoped day of spousall shone,
A mayden Queene, that shone as Titans ray,
As enuying her selfe, that too exceeding shone.
Exceeding shone, like Phoebus fairest childe,
Shapt like a Ladies head, exceeding shone,
For so exceeding shone his glistring ray,
He did receiue, whiles flashing fire about him shone.
Who seeing one that shone in armour faire,
On th'others helmet, which as Titan shone,
Diuinely shone, and two sharpe winged sheares,
And all her steed with tinsell trappings shone,
It shewd it selfe, and shone vnwillingly;
Of massy gold, which with his owne light shone;
The morow next so soone as Titan shone,
Compar'd to her, that shone as Phebes light,
That shone as bright, as doth the heauen sheene;
And wrath, and hatred warely to shonne,
Thenceforth the suit of earthly conquest shonne,
Faire Sir, if euer there ye trauell, shonne
The wandring Islands. Therefore doe them shonne;
Did vse to hide, and plaine apparaunce shonne:)
And light doe shonne, for feare of being shent:
Faire death it is to shonne more shame, to dy:
Or proue thy selfe, this sad encounter shonne,
In vaine he feares that, which he cannot shonne:
Or else for shame, so fowle reproch to shonne,
Ne either car'd to ward, or perill shonne,
That rather seemes, sith knowen armes ye shonne.
That did resort of sinfull people shonne;
My hard mishaps, that ye may learne to shonne;
That makes all men for feare that passage for to shonne.
Ne any may his soueraine power shonne,
The Ladie counseld him the place to shonne,
Ne any paines ne perill did he shonne,
But by all meanes the daunger knowne did shonne:
For aye in darkenesse, which day light doth shonne:
That he descride, and shonned still his slight:
She comes vnsought, and shonned followes eke.
Vpon her fist the bird, which shonneth vew,
Shooke him so hard, that forced him to speake.
